Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the step-parent needs to provide it
Expectation2: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation2: During a casual networking event, someone casually asks about the nature of a client’s case.
Story:
I stood at the edge of the crowded room, swirling my drink, trying to focus on the laughter and chatter around me. As a step-parent, I felt the weight of my family’s needs pressing on my mind—groceries, rent, school supplies. Money was tight, and I knew I had to find new clients if I wanted to keep us afloat. That’s why I was here, mingling, hoping to make connections that might lead to work.

Then, a local business owner sidled up to me, someone who could be a valuable contact. He smiled and asked, “So, what kind of cases are you working on these days?” It was a simple question, but my heart pounded. As a lawyer, I was bound by confidentiality; I couldn’t reveal details about my clients, not even to hint at the high-profile case that might impress him. But I also knew that being open, even just a little, could spark his interest and maybe bring in the business my family desperately needed.

I felt torn, the expectations of my two worlds pulling me in opposite directions. My family’s security or my professional integrity—both demanded loyalty, but I could only choose one.
